title: The Impact of Remittances on Poverty in Mexico
text:
Motivation

In 2023 LMIC countries received USD 669 billion in remittances. Exceeding FDI by USD 250 billion (Ratha et. al. 2023).
Between 2017-2023 Mexico doubled the amount of received remittances, reaching USD 60 billion (2nd largest in the world).
Yet only 5.9% of Mexican households are remittance recipients (representing 24% of their income).

title: The Impact of Remittances on Poverty in Mexico
text:
Motivation

Migration can be positive in a model à la Harris y Todaro (1970), yet negative if households loose their more productive members.
Empirically, people self-select into migration based on observed and unobserved determinants of income (Clemens and Mendola, 2024).
The poorest could spend more in consumption goods (following migrant-members’ preferences) rather than investing on education or health (Haushofer et. al. 2013).
Overall the impact of remittances on poorer households and resource allocation among the poorest is ambiguous.

title: The Impact of Remittances on Poverty in Mexico
text:
This Paper

We study whether remittances impact (extreme) poverty status for individuals in recipient households.
We test if there is a change in households’ patterns of expenses on assets/goods, and the use of consumption credit.
We build a novel data set including information from ENIGH, EMIF, and ACS-IPUMS (2012-2020)
We implement a shift-share mapping US state-by-industry employment for Mexicans (the shifts) into Mexican municipalities using Mexican workers’ patters of migration (the shares).

title: The Impact of Remittances on Poverty in Mexico
text:
What do we know?

Early research correlate remittances with poverty using cross-country panels (Acosta et.al, 2007).
Macro literature has aimed to correct selection, finding reductions in poverty of 5% among recipient households (Chea, 2023).
Our paper relates to Nuñez et. al., (2021) for Mexico and Central America. The authors use distance to the US as instrument.

A 10% increase in remittances translates into a 1.2% reduction in poverty (USD 1.90 a day).

We differentiate by exploiting a plausibly exogenous variation, and by linking this to Mexican poverty measures at the individual-household level.

title: The Impact of Remittances on Poverty in Mexico
text:
What do we learn?

Our results suggest a reduction of poverty for individuals living in remittance recipient households.
The effects are of important magnitude for extreme income poverty, reducing the probability of experiencing it by 33%.
We also document reductions on the probability of multidimensional (extreme) poverty.
Monthly expenses on health five fold (from USD 20).
Housing expenses triple (from USD 50). This is consistent with multidimensional poverty reduction.

title: The Impact of Remittances on Poverty in Mexico
text:
Structural Equation

The equation to be estimated:

\[y_{ihm}=\alpha + \beta R_{hm} + \sum_h x_{ih}'\gamma_h + \varepsilon_{ihm}\]

\(y_{ihm}\) indicates if individual \(i\) in household \(h\) is in poverty
Expenses are measured at the \(h-level\)
\(R_{hm}\) is endogenous, so we instrument.

title: The Impact of Remittances on Poverty in Mexico
text:
Shift-share Instrument

We instrument \(R_{hm}\) using a measure of the exposure of household \(h\) to economic shocks in the US.
For municipality \(m\) in Mexico, tracks changes in employment across US state-industries weighted by migration flows from \(m\) to each US state \(s\): \[
\begin{aligned}
z_{m}=\sum_{s} \frac{M_{ms, t=2012-2017}}{M_{m, t=2012-2017}} \left(\sum_k p_{ks}\Delta_{2019-2020} E_{ks}\right)
\end{aligned}
\]
This follows the recent literature by Borusyak, Hull & Jaravel, (2020) and Goldsmith-Pinkham & Sorkin (2020) formalizing the shift-share strategy.

title: The Impact of Remittances on Poverty in Mexico
text:
Shift-share Instrument
\[
\begin{aligned}
z_{m}=\sum_{s} \frac{M_{ms, t=2012-2017}}{M_{m, t=2012-2017}} \left(\sum_k p_{ks}\Delta_{2019-2020} E_{ks}\right)
\end{aligned}
\]

\(M_{ms}\) is the number of migrants from Mexican municipality \(m\) to the US State \(s\) in 2012-2017
\(M_m\) are total migrants in municipality \(m\) to the US.
\(\Delta E_{ks}\) is the change in employment in industry \(k\) in US state \(s\) in 2019-2020.
\(p_{ks}\) is the share of mexicans working in industry \(k\) in state \(s\).
An alternative version of \(z_m\) defines shifts as \(shift_s=\sum_k\Delta_{2019-2020} E_{ks}\)

title: The Impact of Remittances on Poverty in Mexico
text:
Identification

Assumption is that employment shocks in US are exogenous to Mexican households and were unanticipated for migrants and/or migrants were unable to reallocate during COVID-19 crises.
US Employment shocks impose further restrictions on the income of remittance-recipient households in Mexico.
Households’ level of exposure varies depending on the level of historical relations that each municipality \(m\) has with specific states \(s\) -industry \(k\) in US.

title: The Impact of Remittances on Poverty in Mexico
text:
Shifts

We use the US Census and American Community Survey for employment in industry \(k\)1 by state \(s\) in the US.
This data also allow us to compute the share of mexicans in each US industry \(k\) and state \(s\).
We use sample weights.

Our \(k\) industries are: Agriculture, Mining, Public Services, Construction, Manufacture, Trade, Retail, Transport, Information, Finance, Real Estate, Personal Services, Administrative Services, HHRR, Education, Health, Recreation, Hospitality, and Other services.

Remittances and Poverty

We use the National Survey on Income and Expenses (ENIGH 2020)
Identifies remittance recipient households.
Expenses on education, health, food, and debts among others.
We can measure (multidimensional and extreme) poverty according to CONEVAL’s definitions.

title: The Impact of Remittances on Poverty in Mexico
text:
First Stage

Our shift-share is negatively related with the probability of receiving remittances (due to increase in unemployment).
We estimate:

\[R_{hm}=\rho + \delta \text{shift-share}_{m} + \sum_h x_{ih}'\pi_i + u_{hm}\]

Our main specification includes a set of controls \(x_{ih}\)1

Controls are: households’ head age and its square, members, proportion under age 11, proportion above age 65, proportion of women, a rural indicator, head’s education fixed-effects, municipality population in 2020 and state fixed-effects.

title: The Impact of Remittances on Poverty in Mexico
text:
Conclusions

We find a ~50% lower probability of experiencing multidimensional poverty.
And a 25% to 33% lower chance in the case of income and extreme income poverty.
Recipient Households spend more on health and housing. Consistent with poverty reduction.
Consumption credit rises along with “durables” consumption (TVs, Car and Stoves).
Long term poverty could be reduced through housing and health, yet no effects on education.
Short term affected by higher consumption on “durables”/debt.
